I have episode 1 & 2, but i'm writing my first review on this game for Episode 3.

First off, the sound and visuals are amazing. So many games have very bland graphics to allow for better performance, but after seeing the graphics in this game and it's perfect performance, there is no excuse that other games can't compete. 

The sound is amazing and absolutely adds to the feeling of BEING in the SW world. Very authentic sounds and i'd expect nothing less from ILM. There's nothing like holding a lightsaber next to your head and hearing the hum.

The story mode is short, but these are EPISODES, so that's completely fine. $10 per episode is good. If they make one more that's $40 for a great game. Let's hope they make more than 4.

The story is great. It's different and interesting to see more about Vader's thirst for more power. It does seem more like a guided tour than a campaign mode, but i'm good with that.

Now for the best part (for me) The Lightsaber Dojo.  This episode adds Dual wield sabers (FINALLY), more colors and hilts. It also adds the E-11 Blaster Rifle and Thermal detonators (only at Dojo level 10 so far, maybe there is more to come?) More enemies in the form of new training remotes and stormtroopers (still more to come at higher lvl?)

I'd really like to see all of this technology and effort put into a larger fully fledged FPS in the SW universe. Possibly multiplayer saber battles. Although VR is still kind of niche, if something larger was produced with this kind of love, i think more would get into VR.

I do wish there was a way to run this game in Mixed Reality for video, like Beat Saber. Maybe something to think about adding devs?

review_title: Anticlimactic, but dojo is still awesome
one_reviews_text:
You can finally fight Vader, but it's very scripted and underwhelming. As with the previous episodes, I'm buying this game for the dojo, and it's freaking awesome.

This time they finally added everything I could ask for: dual-wield sabers, bidirectional sabers, blasters and thermal detonators. Back in Episode II I complained that the Force was overpowered, and I'm glad to see that this time they balanced it with two more equally efficient ways to kill enemies.

First is the blaster. Some enemies can resist the Force for a few seconds, but with the blaster you can make it as fast as you can shoot. It's powerful too, as very few enemies can withstand more than 3 shots. That's not to say the blaster is absolutely overpowered, because you still have to aim well, and there's limited ammo, so you may need to Force-grab additional blasters from Stormtroopers.

Second is dual-wielding sabers. With one lightsaber you get the same defensive capabilities as always, but now with a second saber, you have the freedom to slice stunned enemies twice as fast, or immediately deliver a riposte with your spare hand after a parry, or hold both sabers up for an impenetrable guard, or throw and recall the second saber to attack and defend at the same time.

All tools considered I have developed three distinctive fighting styles: defensive saber + Force, defensive saber + blaster, dual sabers. They each have their pros and cons: the Force can take out enemies in pairs, but it takes time; blasters are fast, but there's ammo anxiety, and it can be difficult to grab additional blasters when surrounded; dual-wielding is agile, but it's less efficient for ranged enemies. Because of this I actually have to swap fighting styles back and forth to adapt to the ever-changing enemy layout in later rounds, and I enjoy this very much.

review_title: New features undermine fun of Ep. 1
one_reviews_text:
Gave it 3 stars because Episode II and III pales in comparison to the first Episode. The Lightsabre combat is Vader Immortal's greatest strength, however this fantastic system is wholly undermined by Episodes II and III, thanks to the introduction of comparatively overpowered, imprecise, and finicky Force Powers that feel unpleasant and unresponsive due to an ill-conceived delay when grabbing heavier enemies. The lightsabre becomes relegated exclusively to either a defensive tool for deflecting blaster bolts, or a projectile weapon that is nowhere near as precise or fun to use as a Blaster.

Episode III's dojo has some serious issues too. Using the Blaster is the fastest way to complete the tasks in the allotted time allowed due to their sheer power (which seems absurd for a Lightsabre game), but they don't respawn at the start of every round causing you the hassle of reloading the arena manually. To compound that, if you start a challenge by progressing from an earlier round, you are able to stockpile additional blasters from the previous round (and some of the tight time constraints it's almost as if this was intended.) Which feels like a strange oversight.

As for the final chapter in the campaign, it is really fun albeit brief. It has some of the issues outlined above - the Blaster and the Force becomes the superior option and overshadows the fun of Lightsabre combat. I would have thought the final showdown with Vader would be a longer battle that tested everything you had learned so far. But it doesn't last very long and ends with the VR equivalent of a story-driven QTE event which feels underwhelming.

I'm leaving a review because I hope the developers take some of the lessons learned, and continue to build on this resulting in a truly great VR Star Wars game with more specialisation (such as allowing the Jedi to remain Lightsabre focused by putting cooldowns on the Force Powers and perhaps separate ranged Blaster / Tech classes for Trooper, BH or Smuggler.)

review_title: The best one, but still underwhelming.
one_reviews_text:
Vader Immortal seems like a huge waste of potential. Instead of focusing on 1, medium sized $20 game, they decided to split it into 3 40 minute "episodes," leaving a fractured story that is only harmed further by the mediocre plotline.  
      Episodes 1, 2, and 3 were very underwhelming, they focused on a rather mediocre generic fantasy story, instead of the combat. After the first REAL lightsaber fight, you'll be thinking "Who cares?" anytime the story interrupts. Speaking of story, the story is bogged down by its characters, which range from "The Most Annoying Droid Since The Nasally Droid from Season 5 of Clone Wars," to "Darth Vader but actually Episode 2 Anakin." 
      The main selling point of episode 3 was the final duel against Vader, which is hollow. Vaders moves are badly animated, and very distracting due to the rest of the games great animation. On top of this, it is IMPOSSIBLE to die. I let Vader hit me every time, and never died. This could've been the best fight of the game, but sadly it's bogged down.
     However, the bulk of the game is found in the Lightsaber Dojo, which gives you what you REALLY came for, the Lightsaber combat, and it's a bit underwhelming. The best part is deflecting blaster bolts, which feels incredibley satisified, but sadly the saber vs. saber combat is limited to fighting robots. On multiple occasions I would find my saber failing to block, and the enemies attack phasing through my lightsaber. Don't even bother trying with just the force or a blaster in later levels, as you'll frequently find yourself trying to dodge blaster bolts and lightsaber swings from all directions.
      Overall, I would say Vader Immortal as a series offers too little content for the $30 pricetag. If you're interested in lightsaber vs. lightsaber combat, I would recommend Blade and Sorcery with the Outer Rim mod. However if you want a frantic experience, I would get only Episode 3 of Vader Immortal. The story is not worth the extra $20.

I'm giving it five stars for a reason. As a huge Star Wars fan, I loved the experience. But it's an Experience, and should be priced as such. The entire series is 30$. It's barely worth half of that. Sure, the graphics are amazing, the lightsabers are cool, and the combat is ok. But the story (which enables the combat, lightsabers and graphics) is so terribly short, that I've beaten each Experience in under an hour! That totals about 3 hours total gameplay for the main storyline.

 And the dojo mode? Sure it might give you more to do, but it isn't a sandbox! You don't get all the lightsabers at the start, it isn't free locomotion, (at least the last two weren't, haven't actually played this one's dojo yet since the last two were so similar) so you're stuck in the middle of an incredibly detailed room, standing in one spot as a wave-shooter style of enemies come barreling down on top of you. You can't cover, you can't see all the lightsabers at the start (something this game sorely needs is a gallery you choose from) and the force powers, while yes, being fun when they work, are janky and only do what you want about 50%-40% percent of the time, at least for enemies.

For guns, they worked great, actually. I could force grab a pistol from a downed enemy like it was nothing. Loved that part. Kudos for adding the guns to the dojo, even if you do have to force grab them and can't holster them.

All in all, just wait for a bundle and maybe even a sale to get all 3 at around 15-20 dollars. You'll love the story, but you'll love it even more when you haven't wasted 30$ on a walking simulator, and a dodgy one at that. The main problem is this feels like something that was made to try and sell a larger experience, and there are even subtle hints at that. But it isn't worth paying 30$ to be hinted towards a bigger Star Wars game that may or may not be real at all.

review_title: as game so so, as theme park movie great
one_reviews_text:
If i'd rate this as a game, it would at best get a B- to C from me. Looked at as traditional game, it would be too short, too often block your free movement, just has no challenge at all in story mode (light saber dojo mode has challenge and is more like a traditional game mode).
But after playing the episodes some, it became clear to me that this is not intended to be a game in the traditional sense at all. This is intended to be a fan fantasy fullfillment theme park experience, and as that, it is pretty great, if not excellent.
Graphics and Audio are in a class of their own, very few VR and non VR games and movies come close to this production quality level.
The story and duration is short for usual game standards, but not too short at all when looked at as cinema movie or theme park film.
Basically it is one cinematic moment after the other, never longer than 3-5 minutes doing the same thing. Like as if they made a checklist of what type of Star Wars big cinematic moments could we all have in there, and then they added them all and put one after the other every few minutes. There is a story, with some a bit cheesy worn out moments, some great moments, but to me since i could not stray far from the path nor have branching story choices and the scenery and tasks change constantly, it felt more like the story is there to have a reason to move you from one great Star Wars set piece to another than a world and story one explores freely.
So yeah, if you're looking for a game with constant free movement, challenge etc (in the main story mode, too, not "just" in lightsaber dojo), then you may be disappointed. If you  want a great Star Wars theme park experience, this is hands down the best thing one can have in that field at home right now and really pretty amazing if one thinks about being able to have a theme park experience on this very high visuals, audio and immersion level at home now.
Extra props for the sidekick droid which adds a lot of charm.

Even though this episode has great cinematical moments, they did not have the same impact like standing befor Vader for the first time, wielding the lightsaber while using the force, or fighting a Rancor! While the immersion and the feeling of beeing part of the Star Wars universe, grew from Episode I to Episode II, some how that great feeling got lost entirely in episode III. The long awaited show down with Vader took place way to early and did not feel half as spectacular as the boss fight in Episode II. And after beeing able to sabre throw in the previous episode, it felt wrong not beeing able to do so in this one. I think the lack of interaction, story and charakter development  makes this episode the weakest of the trilogy. And that is very sad as I was looking forward to this episode hoping this would end in an ultimate climax of Star Wars awesomeness. This one nearly felt like a cash grab, compared to the scope of the previous episodes. But as the selling price for all three episodes is still not compareable to a "full length" game ( whatever that length might be in VR ) I only deduct one star, as I would like to compare it to watching an interactive movie. So in retrospect to the whole experience it was definitly worth my while and I am looking forward to go back out there, and search for that treasure ZOE3 was talking about ;)

Thank you ILMxLAB, for fulfilling a childhood dream.

review_title: It could have been so much MORE
one_reviews_text:
I loved the first two episodes, and don't get me wrong, this was still a great game... but the fight with Vader was far too short to be enjoyable. I was left thinking... "that's it"? The entirety of the fight scene lasts what feels like less than minute, which is the whole moment the series was building towards. I was hoping to have a longer or at least somewhat difficult fight against Vader, but instead it was one or two rounds of a faster-paced version of the lightsaber gameplay from the previous episodes. In fact, that's the ONLY time you engage in a lightsaber fight. 

The story simply felt rushed towards the end, to the point that I had very little time to even process what was going on before it ended. Otherwise, the game has wonderful visuals and sound design and it certainly has its moments. I only wish they could have extended some parts and done better with the pacing.

Everything shines in this episode: all the abilities are here (saber, force, blaster) and the story finds a satisfactory end (i still can't believe they touched such an important theme in a VR game).

Of course a lot of things could be better, the limited "VR budget" shows, the story is short, but all things considered the game is exilharating to play and that's the point.
